body_html:
@GuillaumeLeclerc I was just wondering why you need multiple idx_queues and collate_queues. For example, consider a single index queue and collate queue, no NEXT:

[Sampler] -----> index queue    [ (batch 1, idx 1), (batch 1, idx 2), (batch 1, idx 3), ... (batch 1, idx N), (Collate), (batch 2, idx 1) ... ]
                                        |              |
  Workers                              <w1>           <w2>
                                        |              |
                                        v              v
                  collate queue [ f(b1, idx 1), f(b1, idx 2)  ]---<w3>----> [Reorder, Collate]

A worker that gets "Collate" passes to the collate queue and the others continue to work with the index queue.

                                        |              |
                                        v              v

A worker that gets "Collate" passes to the collate queue and the others continue to work with the index queue.
body:
@GuillaumeLeclerc I was just wondering why you need multiple `idx_queue`s and `collate_queue`s. For example, consider a single index queue and collate queue, no NEXT:
```
[Sampler] -----> index queue    [ (batch 1, idx 1), (batch 1, idx 2), (batch 1, idx 3), ... (batch 1, idx N), (Collate), (batch 2, idx 1) ... ]
                                        |              |
  Workers                              <w1>           <w2>
                                        |              |
                                        v              v
                  collate queue [ f(b1, idx 1), f(b1, idx 2)  ]---<w3>----> [Reorder, Collate]
                    
```
A worker that gets "Collate" passes to the collate queue and the others continue to work with the index queue.
